title: Understanding Expressions
text:
In order to understand expressions, we have to break the expressions down into their terms. A term is a group of constants (numbers) and variables (like \(x\)) combined together with various operators like \(\times\) and \(\div\). An expression is a set of terms that are joined together by binary operators \(+\) and \(-\). Here are a few examples of terms and expressions.
Terms
\(4x\)
\(12\)
\(y^2\)
\(\frac{7}{12}\)
Expressions
\(4 + x\)
\(6 - k\)
\(y - x^2\)
\(6x-2y\)

title: Evaluating Expressions
text:
Now for the fun part. For completeness, we are going to evaluate two different kinds of expressions.

Let's start with an expression without variables.
$$5 + 4\times 2^3 - 1$$
When evaluating an expression with no variables, we can simply evaluate by applying BEDMAS.

$$\begin{aligned}
5 + 4\times 2^3 - 1 &= 5 + 4\times 2^3 - 1 &&\text{Exponent}\\
&= 5 + 4\times 8 - 1 &&\text{Multiplication}\\
&= 5 + 32 - 1 &&\text{Addition}\\
&= 37 - 1 &&\text{Subtraction}\\
&= 36 &&\text{$\square$}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Good stuff. Now let's evaluate an expression with variables.

$$\begin{aligned}
x^2 - 5x + 8 &&\text{at $x = 3$}\\
\end{aligned}$$

We have to perform an additional step at the start before we can evaluate, which is to substitute the value given for the variable, in this case \(3\) for \(x\). 

Then evaluate like a simple expression by applying BEDMAS.

$$\begin{aligned}
x^2 - 5x + 8 &= (3)^2 - 5(3) + 8 && \text{substitute in 3 wherever you see $x$}\\
&= 3^2 - 5 \times 3 + 8 &&\text{Exponent}\\
&= 9 - 5 \times 3 + 8 &&\text{Multiplication}\\
&= 9 - 15 + 8 &&\text{Subtraction (since it comes before Addition)}\\
&= -6 + 8 &&\text{Addition}\\
&= 2 &&\text{$\square$}\\
\end{aligned}$$

That's it! Now you know how to evaluate an expression. The next section will explain how we can evaluate expressions to learn about the world around us.

title: Let's Apply What We Learned
text:
Now that we've gone over some examples of expressions and we learned how to evaluate them, let's finish this tutorial off by discussing the value of knowing how to evaluate expressions. Suppose we were given the equation, \(M = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 + mgh\), and we were told that evaluating the expression: \(\frac{1}{2}mv^2 + mgh\) will tell us the amount of mechanical energy present in a physical system. Depending on who you are and what you're interested in, figuring out that information might be important to you and knowing how to evaluate an expression will help you figure it out. To help get the point across, let's do an example and find the mechanical energy of a bowling ball rolling down a bowling alley. $$\text{Suppose we were given a bowling ball that has a mass $m = 4~$kg}$$ $$\text{Find the amount of mechanical energy present when we roll the bowling ball down the alley at a velocity of 4m/s.}$$ To start, let's define the values for our variables: $$m = 4~\text{kg} \quad v = 4~\text{m/s} \quad g = 9.8~\text{m/s} \quad h = 0~\text{m}$$
Note
\(g =\) the gravitational constant for Earth.

\(h =\) the height/distance of the bowling ball relative to the ground/bowling alley.
$$ \begin{aligned} M &= \frac{1}{2}mv^2 + mgh && \text{substitute in our values for $m,v,g$ and $h$}\\ M &= \frac{1}{2}(4)(4)^2 + (4)(9.8)(0) && \text{}\\ M &= 2\cdot 16 + 0\\ M &= 32~\text{J} && \text{$\square$}\\ \end{aligned} $$ What we just learned by evaluating the expression was that the amount of mechanical energy that is present when rolling a bowling ball that weighs \(4~\text{kg}\) down a bowling alley at a velocity of \(4~\text{m/s}\) is 32 Joules (J).
